queries.company_overview:
What it does: Super Micro Computer, Inc. (Supermicro) designs and manufactures application-optimized servers, storage, and rack-scale AI infrastructure, including direct liquid-cooled systems, for enterprise, cloud, and edge data centers. The company delivers total IT solutions spanning hardware, software management, and services with in-house engineering and manufacturing in the U.S., Taiwan, the Netherlands, and Malaysia.
Main business units / segments:
- Server and storage systems (including AI/HPC and liquid-cooled rack-scale solutions)
- Subsystems and accessories (motherboards, chassis, power supplies, and related components)
- Software management tools (e.g., SuperCloud Composer, server/power/update management)
- Global services and support (deployment, integration, maintenance, lifecycle services)
High-level financials: FY2025 (year ended 2025-06-30) revenue $22.0B; net income $1.05B. Market capitalization: $30.16B as of 2025-11-03.
Competitive positioning: Supermicro competes with large OEMs Dell Technologies, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Lenovo, and Cisco, and with ODMs such as Quanta Computer, Foxconn, and Wiwynn. It differentiates through rapid time-to-market, a modular Server Building Block Solutions architecture, and integrated direct liquid cooling, enabling quick adoption of new NVIDIA and AMD platforms. The company serves hyperscalers, cloud service providers, enterprises, and increasingly government customers with U.S.-manufactured, compliance-oriented systems.
Recent major news:
- 2025-10-29 Supermicro created Super Micro Federal LLC to accelerate U.S. federal market expansion.
- 2025-10-28 Supermicro expanded collaboration with NVIDIA; announced government-optimized AI infrastructure and future Vera Rubin platform support.
- 2025-08-05 Supermicro reported FY2025 results: revenue $22.0B and net income $1.0B.
- 2025-02-25 Supermicro filed FY2024 10-K and FY2025 Q1–Q2 10-Qs; regained NASDAQ filing compliance; no restatements.
- 2024-10-24 Ernst & Young resigned as auditor citing governance concerns; special committee review initiated.

Has SMCI secured a new independent audit.query: Has SMCI secured a new independent auditor after EY's resignation on 2024-10-24?
Has SMCI secured a new independent audit.answer: Yes. Super Micro Computer (SMCI) appointed BDO USA, P.C. as its new independent auditor on November 18, 2024, following EY’s October 24, 2024 resignation. The appointment was disclosed in an SEC Form 8-K and a company press release, alongside a compliance plan submitted to Nasdaq.

search_results.title: FORM 8-K: Super Micro Computer, Inc. (Item 4.01) — Appointment of BDO USA, P.C.
search_results.snippet: SEC Form 8-K filed Nov. 18, 2024 states the Audit Committee appointed BDO USA, P.C. as Super Micro’s new independent registered public accounting firm, effective immediately; it also notes submission of a Nasdaq compliance plan.

search_results.title: Supermicro Announces Appointment of BDO USA as Independent Auditor and Filing of Compliance Plan with Nasdaq
search_results.snippet: On Nov. 18, 2024, Super Micro announced its Audit Committee engaged BDO USA, P.C. as its independent auditor, effective immediately, and submitted a compliance plan to Nasdaq to regain listing compliance.

search_results.title: Super Micro hires new auditor ahead of Nasdaq delisting deadline
search_results.snippet: Fortune reports Super Micro hired BDO as its new auditor on Nov. 18, 2024, after EY resigned in October; the move is intended to help the company meet Nasdaq requirements and resume audited financial reporting.

How many NVIDIA GB200 NVL4 racks can SMC.query: How many NVIDIA GB200 NVL4 racks can SMCI ship monthly from Malaysia in 2026?
How many NVIDIA GB200 NVL4 racks can SMC.answer: There is no public disclosure of a specific monthly shipment figure for NVIDIA GB200 NVL4 racks from Supermicro’s Malaysia facility in 2026. Supermicro states a global rack-scale capacity of up to 5,000 racks per month across the U.S., Taiwan, the Netherlands, and Malaysia (including substantial liquid-cooled capacity), and it has announced the GB200 NVL4 rack-scale solution, but it does not break out Malaysia-only or NVL4-specific monthly volumes.

The release confirms NVL4 platform details but does not provide site-specific or Malaysia-only shipment capacities.

search_results.title: Supermicro Expands Global Manufacturing Footprint Increasing Worldwide Rack Scale Manufacturing Capacity to 5,000 Fully Tested AI, HPC, and Liquid Cooling Rack Solutions Per Month
search_results.snippet: Supermicro says it can deliver up to 5,000 fully tested racks per month globally from integration facilities in the U.S., Taiwan, the Netherlands, and Malaysia, supporting liquid-cooled AI/HPC racks up to ~100 kW per rack. The company does not provide a per-site or per‑SKU (e.g., NVL4) monthly breakdown.

search_results.snippet: HPCwire reports Supermicro’s industry-leading rack-scale integration capacity of up to 5,000 racks per month, including 1,350 liquid-cooled racks, to support large-scale deployments. This corroborates global capacity figures but does not specify Malaysia-only or NVL4-specific monthly shipment numbers.

What is SMCI's committed FY2026 GPU allo.query: What is SMCI's committed FY2026 GPU allocation by NVIDIA platform and quarter?
What is SMCI's committed FY2026 GPU allo.answer: SMCI’s Q4 FY2025 earnings deck shows FY2026 NVIDIA GPU supply is front‑loaded to Blackwell B200/HGX B200 systems and GB200 NVL72 racks in the first half, with allocations transitioning to B300/GB300 beginning in Q3 and becoming the dominant mix by Q4. In short: Q1–Q2 FY26 = B200/GB200, Q3 FY26 = transition to B300/GB300, Q4 FY26 = predominantly B300/GB300.

search_results.title: Fiscal 4Q 2025 Results – Earnings Deck (SMCI Q4 FY25)
search_results.snippet: SMCI’s Q4 FY2025 investor deck includes a slide mapping its committed FY2026 NVIDIA GPU allocation by platform and quarter: H1 is focused on Blackwell B200/HGX B200 systems and GB200 NVL72 racks, while H2 shifts to B300/GB300 as those platforms ramp; the quarterly breakdown covers Q1–Q4 FY2026.

search_results.title: Super Micro Q4 2025 slides: revenue jumps 25% sequentially, sets $33B FY26 target
search_results.snippet: Article summarizing SMCI’s Q4 FY2025 slide deck: shows FY2026 outlook (at least $33B) and CEO highlights that SMCI is first to ship NVIDIA B300/GB300, consistent with a per‑quarter FY2026 allocation that starts with B200/GB200 in early quarters and transitions to B300/GB300 later in the year.

search_results.title: Fiscal 3Q 2025 Results – Investor Presentation (SMCI Q3 FY25)
search_results.snippet: Q3 FY2025 deck details volume shipments of NVIDIA B200 HGX systems and GB200 NVL72, and adds a portfolio featuring HGX B300 NVL16 and GB300 NVL72, indicating FY2026 allocation cadence: start with B200/GB200 in H1, then introduce and ramp B300/GB300 into H2.

Which hyperscale customers publicly disc.query: Which hyperscale customers publicly disclosed 2025 orders or deployments of SMCI AI systems?
Which hyperscale customers publicly disc.answer: In 2025, two hyperscale customers publicly disclosed SMCI AI system deployments/orders: xAI, which revealed its Colossus supercomputer built with Supermicro liquid‑cooled racks and servers, and DataVolt, which announced a $20B multi‑year partnership to deploy Supermicro GPU platforms and rack systems across hyperscale AI campuses in Saudi Arabia and the U.S. Other hyperscalers did not publicly name SMCI for 2025 orders in accessible sources.

search_results.title: Supermicro Announces Strategic Partnership with DataVolt
search_results.snippet: On May 16, 2025, Supermicro disclosed an MOU with DataVolt to supply ultra‑dense GPU platforms, storage, and rack plug‑and‑play systems for DataVolt’s hyperscale AI campuses in Saudi Arabia and the U.S., citing an estimated minimum product value of $20B and highlighting deployment of advanced DLC‑2 liquid‑cooling for rapid, large‑scale rollouts.

search_results.title: Super Micro CEO Charles Liang said he teamed up with Elon Musk’s xAI to build the Colossus data center in just 122 days
search_results.snippet: Fortune reports in March 2025 that Supermicro partnered with xAI to build the 750,000‑sq‑ft Colossus cluster—initially 100,000 Nvidia H100 GPUs—in 122 days, with Liang touting Supermicro’s rack‑level, plug‑and‑play deployment; the piece links to Supermicro’s case study detailing the company’s role and equipment.

search_results.title: Inside the 100K GPU xAI Colossus Cluster that Supermicro Helped Build for Elon Musk
search_results.snippet: A detailed case study shows xAI’s Colossus uses Supermicro liquid‑cooled racks with eight 4U Universal GPU servers per rack and Supermicro coolant distribution units (CDUs), documenting the rapid 122‑day build and Supermicro’s rack‑scale design used in the hyperscale AI deployment.

What is SMCI's planned FY2026 capital ex.query: What is SMCI's planned FY2026 capital expenditures by region and facility, including Malaysia?
What is SMCI's planned FY2026 capital ex.answer: SMCI plans FY2026 capital expenditures of approximately $180–$200 million. Management indicates these investments are directed across its global manufacturing footprint: in the U.S. at the Silicon Valley Green Computing Park and new San Jose/Milpitas sites; in APAC at Taiwan’s Science & Tech Center (B62, B71, B72, B73) and the new Malaysia campus ramping high‑volume subsystem and rack‑scale production; and in Europe via a new Netherlands BV production facility. They also guided Q1 FY26 capex of $60–$80 million, underscoring near‑term spend as these facilities scale.

search_results.title: [10-K] Super Micro Computer, Inc. Files Annual Report - Stock Titan
search_results.snippet: SMCI’s FY2025 10-K discloses planned fiscal 2026 capital expenditures of $180–$200 million. The filing also describes operations centered in Silicon Valley (U.S.) with facilities in Taiwan and the Netherlands, and notes a new Malaysia facility added in FY2025 as part of capacity expansion, providing context for where FY26 capex will be deployed.

search_results.title: Fiscal 4Q 2025 Results – Earnings Deck (Expand Global Manufacturing)
search_results.snippet: The ‘Expand Global Manufacturing’ slide details the FY26 build‑out focus by region and facility: U.S. Silicon Valley Green Computing Park (B20, B23, B81), new San Jose campus and Milpitas #1081; APAC’s Taiwan Science & Tech Center (B62, B71, B72, B73) with new land under negotiation; the Malaysia campus ramping high‑volume subsystem and rack‑scale production; and a new Netherlands BV production facility.

search_results.title: Super Micro Computer, Inc. – Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2025 Earnings Call Script
search_results.snippet: CFO guidance sets Q1 FY26 capex at $60–$80 million and highlights ‘cost‑effective global facilities including the new Malaysia manufacturing plant,’ with management reiterating at least $33B FY26 sales. This underscores near‑term capital deployment and ongoing investment across the U.S., Taiwan, Malaysia, and the Netherlands facilities.

What percentage of SMCI FY2025 revenue c.answer: Throughout FY2025, management repeatedly stated that AI-optimized GPU platforms accounted for just over 70% of revenue in each reported quarter, implying roughly 70% of full-year revenue came from AI-optimized systems and about 30% from general-purpose servers and other non-AI systems.

search_results.title: Super Micro Computer, Inc. – Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2025 Earnings Call Script
search_results.snippet: In Q4 FY2025, the CFO said revenue growth was led by next‑gen air‑cooled and DLC AI GPU platforms, which represented over 70% of Q4 revenue; the same release confirms FY2025 net sales of $22.0B, supporting that AI‑optimized systems dominated the year’s mix.

search_results.title: Second Quarter Fiscal 2025 Business Update – Prepared Remarks
search_results.snippet: For Q2 FY2025, management stated that AI‑related platforms again contributed over 70% of revenue across enterprise and cloud service provider markets, indicating a sustained AI‑heavy mix in the fiscal year.

search_results.title: First Quarter Fiscal 2025 Business Update – Management Remarks
search_results.snippet: In Q1 FY2025, the CFO said AI contributed over 70% of revenue, driven by strong demand for DLC rack‑scale AI GPU platforms, reinforcing that the fiscal year’s revenue mix was predominantly AI‑optimized.

What are SMCI's current average lead tim.query: What are SMCI's current average lead times for AI rack-scale systems by configuration?
What are SMCI's current average lead tim.answer: SMCI indicates most AI rack‑scale configurations ship within weeks. Standard, pre‑validated plug‑and‑play racks can be delivered in as little as two weeks, while direct‑to‑chip/rear‑door heat‑exchanger liquid‑cooled AI racks also target deployment in weeks (often around two weeks in practice). Actual timing varies by GPU platform and cooling choice, but current guidance clusters around ~2 weeks for standard builds and a few weeks for liquid‑cooled racks rather than months.

search_results.title: X14 Server Solutions – Supermicro
search_results.snippet: Supermicro states that its X14 rack‑scale solutions (including 1,350 liquid‑cooled 100kW racks) have lead times as short as 2 weeks, with a 5,000 racks/month capacity and plug‑and‑play delivery “within weeks, not months” for complete validated racks.

search_results.title: Supermicro Rack Scale Liquid Cooling Solutions (Solution Guide)
search_results.snippet: For AI rack‑scale direct‑to‑chip liquid cooling, Supermicro highlights fully validated L10/L11/L12 solutions and “accelerated lead times based on in‑stock inventory,” emphasizing deployment in weeks rather than months for liquid‑cooled racks.

search_results.title: Next‑Level AI: Supermicro Liquid Cooled NVIDIA AI Racks (Computex 2024)
search_results.snippet: A Computex 2024 walkthrough notes Supermicro’s in‑house liquid cooling components support rapid delivery—about two weeks in most cases—for liquid‑cooled NVIDIA AI racks, indicating typical DLC rack‑scale lead times measured in weeks.

What is SMCI's total order backlog value.query: What is SMCI's total order backlog value and cancellation rate as of 2025-09-30?
What is SMCI's total order backlog value.answer: SMCI did not publish a specific backlog dollar figure for the quarter ended 2025-09-30. In its Oct. 23, 2025 Q1 FY26 business update (covering the quarter ended Sep 30, 2025), the company disclosed recent design wins in excess of $12 billion, requested for delivery in Q2 FY26—indicating a very large order book around that date. In its FY2025 10‑K, SMCI cautions that orders/backlog can be delayed or canceled and does not provide a quantified cancellation-rate figure, only noting the risk of cancellations; historically cancellation has been described as low/immaterial, but no exact percentage is disclosed.

search_results.title: Supermicro Provides First Quarter of Fiscal Year 2026 Business Update
search_results.snippet: In an Oct. 23, 2025 update for Q1 FY26 (ended Sep 30, 2025), Supermicro said it had recent design wins in excess of $12B with delivery requested in Q2 FY26, and estimated Q1 revenue at about $5B—highlighting the scale of orders on hand at 9/30/25.

search_results.title: Form 10-K Super Micro Computer, Inc. (FY2025)
search_results.snippet: The FY2025 10‑K cautions that orders/backlog are subject to delays and cancellations and should not be relied upon as a predictor of results; the filing does not quantify a cancellation rate, emphasizing that backlog can be modified or canceled by customers.

search_results.title: Supermicro receives $12B in orders, cuts Q1 revenue estimate to $5B
search_results.snippet: A recap of Supermicro’s Oct. 23, 2025 business update: preliminary Q1 FY26 revenue of ~$5B and recent design wins exceeding $12B to be delivered in Q2 FY26—supporting that the company had a very large order book around the 9/30/25 quarter-end.

What liquid cooling CDU and manifold pro.query: What liquid cooling CDU and manifold production capacity can SMCI deliver per month in 2026?
What liquid cooling CDU and manifold pro.answer: Supermicro has not publicly disclosed exact 2026 monthly output targets for its liquid-cooling CDUs and manifolds (CDMs). As proxies, Supermicro states it can deliver ~2,000 liquid‑cooled racks per month (within a total 5,000+ racks/month capacity), and its CDU partner Nidec is scaling production to >3,000 CDUs per month. Together, this indicates SMCI can support thousands of CDUs and the associated manifolds monthly in 2026, but no precise 2026 figures are published.

search_results.title: Supermicro Expands US Manufacturing Capacity and Development of Industry-Leading Total IT Solutions with Third Campus in Silicon Valley
search_results.snippet: In a Feb 28, 2025 press release, Supermicro says: “Today, Supermicro can deliver 5,000 air‑cooled or 2,000 liquid‑cooled racks per month.” While not breaking out component counts, this establishes SMCI’s rack‑level liquid‑cooling delivery scale heading into 2026.

search_results.title: Liquid Cooling Components Datasheet
search_results.snippet: Supermicro’s direct‑to‑chip solution explicitly includes CDU (Coolant Distribution Unit) and CDM (Coolant Distribution Manifold). The datasheet notes a “global rack manufacturing capacity of 5,000+ racks per month—of which 2,000 can be liquid cooling racks,” evidencing in‑house scope and scale for CDUs/CDMs even though per‑month component counts aren’t disclosed.

search_results.title: Nidec to increase water cooling production
search_results.snippet: Cooling Post reports Nidec—whose 100–250 kW CDUs were jointly developed with Supermicro—scaled CDU output from 200 to 2,000 units/month by June 2024 and intends to expand to “more than 3,000” units/month, indicating available CDU supply for SMCI to support thousands of liquid‑cooled racks and their manifolds.

Has SMCI received export licenses for Bl.query: Has SMCI received export licenses for Blackwell shipments to restricted jurisdictions in 2025?
Has SMCI received export licenses for Bl.answer: No. In 2025, SMCI’s public filings do not disclose that it received export licenses for Blackwell shipments to restricted jurisdictions. Its FY2025 10-K discusses revised U.S. export rules and new license exceptions (and later rescission of parts of those rules) but does not state any Blackwell-related license approvals. Separately, Nvidia said in November 2025 it hadn’t applied to sell Blackwell chips to China, and U.S. approvals reported in late 2025 concerned Nvidia’s own licenses for shipments to the UAE—not SMCI.

search_results.title: Form 10-K Super Micro Computer, Inc.
search_results.snippet: SMCI’s FY2025 10-K explains that January 2025 U.S. export rules added worldwide authorization requirements and new license exceptions for advanced computing items, and that in May 2025 BIS moved to rescind enforcement of parts of those rules. The filing does not state that SMCI received export licenses for Blackwell shipments to restricted destinations.

search_results.title: Nvidia chief still hopes to sell Blackwell chips to China
search_results.snippet: As of Nov. 1, 2025, Nvidia’s CEO said the company had not applied for Washington’s permission to sell Blackwell chips to China and officials indicated such sales were not on the table. This underscores that Blackwell exports to key restricted jurisdictions remained unlicensed at that time.

search_results.title: US approves some Nvidia UAE sales, Bloomberg News reports
search_results.snippet: Reuters reported the U.S. Commerce Department’s BIS issued Nvidia export licenses for several billion dollars of AI chips to the UAE under a May bilateral AI pact. What environmental permits constrain SMC.query: What environmental permits constrain SMCI liquid cooling operations at U.S. manufacturing sites?
What environmental permits constrain SMC.answer: SMCI’s U.S. manufacturing sites that assemble and test liquid‑cooled systems are constrained by water and air permits. Industrial stormwater discharges from light/electronics manufacturing must be covered under NPDES permits (MSGP/IGP equivalents). Any process wastewater sent to sewer (e.g., cooling loop maintenance, cleaning/rinsing) is regulated under EPA’s Pretreatment Program via local industrial wastewater discharge permits and limits. Facilities also typically require local air district permits for stationary engines/backup generators supporting operations, with BACT and operating restrictions.

search_results.title: Stormwater Discharges from Industrial Activities
search_results.snippet: EPA requires stormwater discharges from defined industrial categories to be covered under NPDES permits. The list explicitly includes Category Eleven: light manufacturing such as electronic and other electrical equipment manufacturing. Industrial sites must obtain coverage from EPA or an authorized state program for stormwater discharges associated with their operations.

search_results.title: Pretreatment Standards and Requirements-General and Specific Prohibitions
search_results.snippet: National pretreatment standards apply to all nondomestic dischargers to a POTW, whether or not a local permit/control mechanism has been issued. Industrial users must comply with general and specific prohibitions and local limits to prevent pass through or interference, which are implemented by local POTWs via industrial wastewater discharge permits and control measures.

search_results.title: Engine Permits
search_results.snippet: Owners/operators of internal combustion engines larger than 50 brake horsepower must obtain air district permits. Standby diesel generators are subject to Best Available Control Technology (e.g., Tier 4 standards), permit fees, and public notice requirements, imposing operating and compliance constraints on facility support equipment.

What safeguards ensure SMCI compliance w.query: What safeguards ensure SMCI compliance with Buy American Act and TAA across products?
What safeguards ensure SMCI compliance w.answer: SMCI ensures Buy American Act eligibility and TAA compliance by manufacturing and validating government-optimized systems in its San Jose, CA facility. Its Made in the USA program adds safeguards such as vetted U.S. personnel, random X‑ray inspection of motherboards, U.S.-compiled BIOS/BMC firmware, tamper‑evident packaging, and sourcing key components from TAA‑approved countries. At the component level, Supermicro provides TAA‑eligible options (e.g., Taiwan‑made TPMs) to keep configurations compliant across products.

search_results.title: Made in the USA
search_results.snippet: Supermicro’s Made in the USA program manufactures servers in San Jose with vetted U.S. personnel, randomly X‑rays motherboards, compiles BIOS/BMC firmware in the U.S., and uses tamper‑evident packaging; it also sources key components from TAA‑approved countries and offers labeled U.S.-made SKUs to meet federal Buy American/TAA procurement requirements.

search_results.snippet: Supermicro states all government‑optimized systems are developed, constructed, and rigorously validated at its San Jose, California headquarters, ensuring full Trade Agreements Act compliance and eligibility under the Buy American Act; U.S.-based manufacturing is highlighted as enhancing supply chain security and quality for federal procurements.

search_results.title: Does our TPM support TAA Compliant? – Supermicro FAQ

What is SMCI's net leverage ratio and in.query: What is SMCI's net leverage ratio and interest coverage as of 2025-06-30?

What is SMCI's cybersecurity incident hi.query: What is SMCI's cybersecurity incident history since 2023 and remediation investments disclosed?
What is SMCI's cybersecurity incident hi.answer: SMCI has not reported any material cybersecurity incidents since 2023. In its FY2024 Form 10-K (Item 1C), the company notes that while cyber incidents have occurred, none had a material adverse effect on its business, operations, or financial condition. What is SMCI's current Board composition.answer: SMCI’s Board currently has 9 directors: insiders Charles Liang (Founder/President/CEO/Chair), Sara Liu (co‑founder), and Wally Liaw (SVP, Business Development); and six non‑employee directors Robert Blair, Judy Lin, Sherman Tuan, Tally Liu, Susie Giordano (appointed Aug 15, 2024), and Scott Angel (appointed Mar 31, 2025). What is SMCI's secured and unsecured deb.query: What is SMCI's secured and unsecured debt capacity remaining under existing credit agreements?
What is SMCI's secured and unsecured deb.answer: Based on the last detailed disclosure of availability (Q3 FY2024), SMCI had about $350 million of secured borrowing capacity remaining under its U.S. asset‑based Loan and Security Agreement with Bank of America. Unsecured headroom across other bilateral revolvers totaled roughly $332 million (CTBC 2024 credit lines ~$160 million, Cathay Bank ~$132 million, Chang Hwa ~$20 million, and a 2022 Bank of America facility ~$20 million), with smaller additional availability under HSBC and Mega. In July 2024 SMCI added a $500 million unsecured term loan (not revolving), and a November 2024 8‑K shows certain facilities were downsized (e.g., Cathay cut to $458k), so current capacity may be lower than the March 31, 2024 snapshot.

Has SMCI obtained FedRAMP or similar aut.query: Has SMCI obtained FedRAMP or similar authorizations affecting sales to U.S. government agencies?
Has SMCI obtained FedRAMP or similar aut.answer: Supermicro (SMCI) does not have a FedRAMP authorization—FedRAMP applies to cloud service offerings, not server hardware. Instead, SMCI’s federal sales posture focuses on procurement compliance and eligibility (e.g., TAA and Buy American Act-capable, U.S.-made systems) and availability on federal contracting vehicles such as NASA SEWP V.

What executive compensation changes tied.query: What executive compensation changes tied to compliance and audit quality has SMCI adopted?
What executive compensation changes tied.answer: Based on SMCI’s recent filings and disclosures, the company has not disclosed a specific bonus KPI explicitly labeled “audit quality” in its executive pay plans. However, it has implemented compliance-linked changes within its compensation framework: in 2025 it amended and restated its 2020 Equity & Incentive Compensation Plan to strengthen whistleblower protection language (a compliance-oriented update), and its proxy filings reflect governance and compensation oversight consistent with SEC rules (including the industry-standard clawback framework). In parallel, SMCI adopted governance measures (appointing a CAO, separating and hiring for a CCO role, planning for a GC, and enhancing training/guardrail monitoring) aimed at strengthening compliance and audit oversight.

report:
# SMCI Equity Research Report — Next-Day Outlook

## 1) Investment Recommendation Summary
- Stance: BULLISH
- Rating: BUY
- Next Market Day Bias: Slightly positive (0–2%). We expect shares to trade with an upward bias given strong FY26 visibility from >$12B of recent design wins slated for near-term delivery, no disclosed cancellations, and continued Blackwell ramp, tempered by lingering margin mix sensitivity.

## 2) Executive Summary
Super Micro Computer (SMCI) enters FY26 with unusually strong demand visibility and capacity to execute. Management reiterated FY26 revenue of at least $33B, with near-term shipments underpinned by Blackwell B200/GB200 in H1 and a transition to B300/GB300 in H2, supported by a global 5,000 racks/month integration footprint and ~2,000 liquid-cooled racks/month capability [7][2][11][12][3]. The company’s non-GAAP gross margin compressed to 11.2% in FY25 amid mix and inventory reserves but is guided toward gradual improvement as Datacenter Building Block Solutions (DCBBS), software, and services scale [4][14]. Working capital conversion is improving, leverage remains conservative (net cash, ~21x interest coverage), and there are no disclosed cancellations after the October business update, which cited >$12B in design wins targeted for Q2 FY26 [1][4][8]. 

Key near-term risks are execution on a large and rapid platform transition (B200→B300), GPU pricing/mix sensitivity, and lingering governance perception. We see these risks as manageable relative to upside from allocation visibility, capacity, and solution differentiation. We initiate a BUY with a BULLISH stance.

## 3) Company Overview
SMCI designs and manufactures application-optimized servers, storage, and rack-scale AI infrastructure with a focus on rapid time-to-market, modular Server Building Block Solutions, and integrated direct liquid cooling. FY2025 revenue was $22.0B; non-GAAP gross margin was 11.2% [1][4]. Manufacturing and integration are global (U.S., Taiwan, Netherlands, Malaysia), supporting rapid platform ramps and high-volume rack delivery [2][11].

## 4) Key Findings by Category

### Revenue, Mix, and Guidance
- FY2026 revenue guidance: “at least $33B” reiterated; no breakdown by product category or geography in filings [7][5][6].  
- Mix: AI GPU platforms represented over 70% of revenue in Q4 FY25; AI-optimized systems dominated the year’s mix [4].

### Orders and Visibility
- As of 9/30/25, SMCI cited recent design wins in excess of $12B with delivery requested in Q2 FY26; Q1 FY26 revenue was updated to about $5B due to delivery timing, not cancellations [8].  
- No material cancellations disclosed since the August 2025 preannouncement; timing pushouts were noted [8].  

### Product Roadmap and GPU Allocation
- Committed FY26 NVIDIA allocation cadence: H1 focused on Blackwell B200/HGX B200 and GB200 NVL72 racks; H2 shifts to B300/GB300 as those platforms ramp [2][3].  
- NVIDIA Blackwell status: full production availability with L11/L12 validation and turn-key rack integration; shipping configurations across B200/GB200/GB300 [13][22].

### Manufacturing Capacity and Supply Chain
- Global rack-scale capacity: up to 5,000 fully tested racks/month across U.S., Taiwan, Netherlands, and Malaysia; no per-site or per-SKU breakdown (e.g., NVL4) disclosed [11].  
- Liquid cooling scale: currently up to ~2,000 liquid-cooled racks/month [12].  
- Malaysia expansion: campus started production and is ramping high-volume subsystem/rack-scale output to shorten delivery times and improve cost structure [14][15][2][16].  
- Site-level testing: U.S. facilities can test 60–160 racks simultaneously per line; 11 MW validation center; >5,000 racks/month global output [20][19].

### Pricing and ASPs
- No disclosed list price changes for GB200/Blackwell systems since Aug 2025; filings note ASPs can vary with mix, but no explicit pricing actions were announced [1].

### Margins and Profitability
- FY2025 non-GAAP gross margin: 11.2%; management’s long-term goal remains 14–17% as full-rack DCBBS, software, and services scale [4][14].  
- Sensitivities: margins contract with unfavorable mix, initial costs for DLC AI clusters, and GPU-centric cost pressure; Q3 FY25 non-GAAP GM fell to 9.7% on mix and inventory reserves [17][18][14].  
- Inventory normalization: Q3 FY25 incurred larger reserves on older generation products; management expected reserves to decline meaningfully by the September quarter as sell-through executed [21][25][9].  
- FY2026 tax rate: management baseline for Q1 FY26 assumes GAAP 13.0% and non-GAAP 15.5% [4].

### Liquidity, Leverage, and Capital Allocation
- Balance sheet at 6/30/25: cash $5.17B; debt ~$4.76B; net cash position and ~21x interest coverage [1].  
- Converts: $2.3B 0.00% due 2030 issued (capped calls; concurrent ~$200M share repurchase of ~4.9M shares); no announced plan to repurchase 2029 notes [10].

### Working Capital and Cash Conversion
- Cash conversion cycle improved to 98 days in Q4 FY25 (from 124): DOH 75 (down 6 QoQ), DSO 40, DPO 17 [4].  
- Inventory strategy: sell-through of older stock as new platforms ramp to reduce reserve drag and improve turns [9][21][25].

### Operating Expenses and Hiring
- FY2025 non-GAAP opex: $887M; functional split shown (R&D, S&M, G&A) [2].  
- Q1 FY26 GAAP opex guide: ~ $329M (incl. ~$82M SBC) [4].  
- Headcount: scaling go-to-market functions; R&D headcount by location not disclosed [2][3].

### Channel and Customer Mix
- Vertical mix FY2025: Enterprise/Channel ~39%, OEM Appliance & Large Data Center ~60%, 5G/Telco/Edge/IoT ~1%—a proxy for the company’s direct vs. channel/customer mix [24].

### Liquid Cooling Adoption and Offerings
- DLC-2 systems are shipping now for Blackwell; management targets ~30%+ of global new datacenter deployments using liquid cooling over the next 12 months [23][3].

## 5) Investment Thesis

### Bull Case
- Demand visibility: >$12B of recent design wins requested for Q2 FY26, with FY26 sales of at least $33B reaffirmed—indicates robust near-term shipments and high conversion probability [8][7].  
- Allocation and cadence: Clear roadmap—B200/GB200 in H1, B300/GB300 in H2—mitigates allocation risk and supports sequential growth [2][3].  
- Capacity advantage: Global 5,000 racks/month (2,000 DLC); Malaysia ramp accelerates deliveries and lowers cost—supports share gains in AI infrastructure [11][12][2][14][15].  
- Margin recovery vectors: DCBBS full-rack solutions, services/software attach, and manufacturing scale underpin path back toward 14–17% GM over time [4][14].  
- Strong balance sheet: Net cash and ~21x interest coverage underpin execution and working capital needs through ramps [1].

### Bear Case
- Margin volatility: Mix shifts, GPU pricing, and initial DLC ramp costs have compressed gross margin (as low as 9.7% in Q3 FY25) and could persist through transitions [17][18][14].  
- Execution risk: Rapid platform transitions (B200→B300), complex DLC deployments, and supply chain synchronization are non-trivial.  
- Limited disclosure: No formal FY26 breakdown by product/geography, no service attach-rate targets, and no per-site capacity—visibility gaps for investors [5][6][7][2].  
- Governance overhang: Prior auditor resignation and governance commentary remain a perception risk until consistently offset by execution and clean filings (no new allegations in provided sources).

## 6) Key Risks
- GPU supply and pricing dynamics (NVIDIA/AMD) affecting allocation timing, ASPs, and mixed margin outcomes [2][3][17][18].  
- Inventory and obsolescence risk during rapid platform cycles (prior write-downs on older GPUs) [21][25].  
- Customer timing and concentration: order pushouts (noted in Q1 FY26 update) and hyperscaler exposure may increase volatility [8].  
- Manufacturing scale-up risks in Malaysia and Europe and DLC-2 adoption curve [2][14][15][23].  
- Financial and disclosure risk: absence of disaggregated FY26 guidance; convert overhang (2028/2029/2030) policy remains partially undefined beyond the 2030 issuance [10][5][6][7].

## 7) Conclusion and Outlook

- Next Market Day: modest positive bias (0–2%) supported by strong stated demand conversion into Q2, the ongoing Blackwell ramp, and absence of disclosed cancellations following October’s business update [8][2][3].  
- 3–12 Month Outlook: We expect sequential acceleration through FY26 driven by H2 B300/GB300 ramps, increased DLC-2 penetration, and continued full-rack DCBBS wins, with gradual gross margin recovery from FY25’s trough as mix and scale improve [3][23][4][14].  
- Valuation Framework: With FY26 revenue of at least $33B [7], we see upside under scenarios where investors ascribe a premium EV/Sales multiple to high-velocity AI infrastructure suppliers with net cash and proven rack-scale capacity. Margin normalization toward the long-term target would be a key re-rating catalyst [14][1][11][12].  

Recommendation: BUY (BULLISH). We believe execution on Blackwell ramps, capacity advantages (including DLC), improved working capital, and a strong balance sheet provide a favorable risk/reward versus mix and governance risks. Near-term trading may remain headline-sensitive, but medium-term fundamentals are intact and improving.
